docs.lead_paragraph: The government has notified hundreds of thousands of people that information provided for subsidized health insurance did not match other federal documents and they may risk losing their subsidies.

headline.main: Thousands to Be Questioned on Eligibility for Health Insurance Subsidies
headline.print_headline: Thousands to Be Questioned on Eligibility for Health Insurance Subsidies

docs.abstract: Obama administration is contacting hundreds of thousands of people with subsidized health insurance to resolve questions about their eligibility, as consumer advocates express concern that many will be required to repay some or all subsidies; of eight million people who signed up for private health plans through insurance exchanges under new health care law, two million reported personal information that differed from data in government records.
docs.snippet: The government has notified hundreds of thousands of people that information provided for subsidized health insurance did not match other federal documents and they may risk losing their subsidies.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Through an unusual arrangement with Arizona State University, the company will pay for its workers to earn college degrees.

headline.main: Starbucks to Provide Free College Education to Thousands of Workers
headline.print_headline: Starbucks to Provide Free College Education to Thousands of Workers

docs.abstract: Starbucks announces arrangement with Arizona State University to provide free online college education to thousands of its workers; program is open to any of company's 135,000 United States employees, provided they work at least 20 hours a week and meet admissions requirements; employees who take advantage are not required to remain with Starbucks after their education.
docs.snippet: Through an unusual arrangement with Arizona State University, the company will pay for its workers to earn college degrees.

docs.lead_paragraph: The way we fund their benefits makes it too easy to go to war.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Cato Institute scholars Michael F Cannon and Christopher Preble contends Department of Veteran Affairs helps inflict great harm on veterans, active-duty military personnel and civilians due to the way it is funded; notes veterans' benefits are typically funded 40 or 50 years after military conflicts end, and suggests this makes it too easy to go to war; proposes system of veterans' benefits to be funded by Congress in advance.
docs.snippet: The way we fund their benefits makes it too easy to go to war.

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
keywords.name: subject

byline.original: By MICHAEL F. CANNON and CHRISTOPHER A. PREBLE

docs.lead_paragraph: Silence on the salaries reigns supreme at Madison Square Garden, but in recent months, former N.F.L. cheerleaders have accused teams of violating labor laws.

headline.main: Dancing for the Knicks Is a Coveted Opportunity, but the Salary Is a Secret
headline.print_headline: Dancing for the Knicks Is a Coveted Opportunity, but the Salary Is a Secret

docs.abstract: Rachel L Swarns The Working Life column observes that salary of Knicks City Dancers, cheerleaders for New York Knicks, is a secret; notes that some women auditioning for the cheerleading team are struck by fact that salary is never discussed, but most are just concerned with making the cut.
docs.snippet: Silence on the salaries reigns supreme at Madison Square Garden, but in recent months, former N.F.L. cheerleaders have accused teams of violating labor laws.

docs.lead_paragraph: Germany coach Joachim Loew was finally able to pronounce a clean bill of health for his players at the World Cup on Sunday and immediately sounded a confident note on the eve of their opening match against Portugal.    The dramatic airlift by helicopter of Bastian Schweinsteiger from their camp at Santa Cruz Cabralia on Saturday was no more than a routine check at a nearby hospital on his recent knee injury, requested by FIFA for insurance purposes, said the coach.

headline.main: Clean Bill of Health Has Loew Glowing With Confidence
headline.print_headline: Clean Bill of Health Has Loew Glowing With Confidence

docs.abstract: Many dads are far more involved at home than their fathers were. But a new study suggests workplaces may not have caught up, ANNA NORTH writes.

docs.lead_paragraph: It's crunch time at the Supreme Court, where the justices are racing to issue opinions in 17 cases over the next two weeks.

docs.lead_paragraph: How to insure against the risks of investing in a college education? Allow student loan payments to rise and fall with the borrower’s income.

headline.main: Finding Shock Absorbers for Student Debt
headline.print_headline: Finding Shock Absorbers for Student Debt

docs.abstract: The Upshot; Susan Dynarski Economic View column welcomes executive order signed by Pres Obama that will ease debt burden on millions of American students, but argues that it does not go far enough; suggests that to adequately insure students against the risk of investing in college, government should allow student-loan payments to rise and fall with their income.
docs.snippet: How to insure against the risks of investing in a college education? Allow student loan payments to rise and fall with the borrower’s income.
